title: Hodbarrow Lakes Nature Reserve Walking Route

images.title: Hodbarrow lighthouse by Steve Fareham, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hodbarrow lighthouse. Both the old and new lighthouses are located on the Duddon estuary and were established to assist navigation for ships exporting ore from Hodbarrow Mine.

images.title: Hodbarrow lagoon by Steve Fareham, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hodbarrow lagoon

images.title: malcolm tebbit / The wind blows, Haverigg harbour
images.caption: The wind blows, Haverigg harbour

images.title: Andrew Hill / Hodbarrow reserve, looking to old lighthouse
images.caption: Hodbarrow reserve, looking to old lighthouse

images.title: Resurfaced path to the Old Lighthouse by Perry Dark, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Resurfaced path to the Old Lighthouse. Located 380m north-west of Hodbarrow Point, to the south of Millom. Built in the 19th Century, it is one of the last surviving structures of the Hodbarrow Mine, which once shipped iron ore as far as Germany. Hodbarrow Beacon is a Scheduled Monument.

images.title: Duck watching point on Hodbarrow RSPB site. by Steve Fareham, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Duck watching point on Hodbarrow RSPB site.

images.title: Oystercatchers, Haverigg Harbour by Richard Law, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Oystercatchers, Haverigg Harbour on the western side of the site.

images.title: Andrew Hill / Near Hodbarrow point, ruined windmill on skyline
images.caption: Near Hodbarrow point, ruined windmill on skyline. The old windmill was used by Hodbarrow Iron Ore Mine to store gunpowder, used for blasting, between 1855 and 1880, when a purpose-built facility was built. It is located at the south eastern end of the reserve.

description: Enjoy a walk around Hodbarrow Lakes RSPB on the edge of the Lake District National Park. You can stroll along the sea wall and enjoy fine views of the reserve's lakes on one side and the Duddon Estuary on the other. Look out for Teal, Widgeon, Coot, Mallard, Tufted Duck, Common Pochard, Goldeneye and Red-breasted Merganser as you make your way around the reserve. You can also sometimes see seals in the estuary. The reserve is located just a short walk from the centre of Millom. The Cumbria Coastal Way runs past the reserve so you could pick this up and head along the coast towards Ravenglass if you would like to continue your walk. A climb to Black Combe is also a good option.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Millom Walk visits the site from the train station in the nearby town. For more walking ideas in the area see the Lake District Walks page.

display_address: Outer Barrier, Steel Green, Haverigg, Millom, Cumberland, England, LA18 4LG, United Kingdom
